text: 5) Almost forgot: Props to Klobuchar for working Prince and the greatest ever Super Bowl halftime performance into her speech: “If Prince can do a halftime show in all that rain, I can do this in the snow."
author: AndyKroll

text:
4) Klobuchar's one of the very few senators to ask consistently tough & educated questions of the tech goliaths. 

Putting them in her rollout speech is a heartening sign that maybe we'll get a real debate in 2020 about monopolies and tech's takeover of our data and our lives.
author: AndyKroll

text: 3) And her choice of "obstacles" struck me as particularly attuned to the times: Voting rights, climate change, Big Tech...
author: AndyKroll

text:
2) She had a mantra for today: "The obstacles? They are our path." 

Most 2020ers have a similar line, but Klobuchar's struck me as both memorable and powerful. She doesn't dance around how massive the challenges we face are; she's says she wants us all to run straight at them.
author: AndyKroll

text:
1) "Disaster" was my first thought at seeing the near-whiteout conditions for her speech. Then I watched all 25-ish mins of it, and damn, she owned it. 

Made it look so natural it was almost as if she'd planned for it. That takes poise, even for a MNan.

text:
All in all, hard not to come away from today thinking @KamalaHarris is looking like the formidable candidate many thought she'd be. 

I'm eager to hear more policy specifics of course, & to see how she deals w/ her first big setback, mistake, etc. But a powerful start for her 8/
author: AndyKroll

text: Also have to note Harris' refreshingly good taste in music. She walked out to Mary J. Blige, quoted Bob Marley in her speech. "Fight Song" on repeat this is not. 7/
author: AndyKroll

text: On @KamalaHarris' speech today. Good pt on the nat'l security side...
author: AndyKroll

text: I do wish she'd said more about climate change, the existential crisis of our time. What we got was one shout-out and...that was it. 6/
author: AndyKroll

text: Truth and "for the people," suggesting a sort of progressive populism, is an equally potent mix. She didn't disappoint (with one exception) in the policy portion, pledging to pass Medicare for All, debt-free college, reproductive parity, and tax breaks for the middle class. 5/
author: AndyKroll

text:
Two big themes stuck out: Truth and "for the people." We got a preview of this with the release of Harris' book, "The Truths We Hold." "For the people," of course, is her campaign slogan.

Early in the speech, she gave what to my mind was one potent line: 4/
author: AndyKroll

text: For me, the speech itself was solid, if not particularly memorable. Heavy on values, "who we are" as Americans, more that unites than divides us, etc. An essential message, no doubt, but something you'll hear from most of the 2020 contenders. 3/
author: AndyKroll

text:
The event itself was impressive: The crowd estimated at some 20,000, the American flags and stage in front of Oakland City Hall.

Of the 2020 rollouts thus far, Harris' is the best. Hat's off to her campaign: The Monday video teasing the Sunday event played out quite well. 2/
author: AndyKroll

text:
.@BreNichelle08 at @amprog maternal and infant mortality event points out the small percentage of black OBGYNs as baking bias into childbirth.

@ByNinaMartin adds that that same bias is prevalent in health care education and training as well.
author: AndyKroll

text:
Research shows a direct connection between infant mortality rates and states that expanded Medicaid access, @myrajonestaylor says. 

Your daily reminder that expanding Medicaid flat-out saves lives, young and old.
author: AndyKroll

text:
.@myrajonestaylor of @ZEROTOTHREE lists off the key post-childbirth resources to prevent infant mortality:

- basic necessities at home
- paid family medical leave
- a high-quality, safe, early learning environment when parent/caregiver goes back to work
author: AndyKroll

text: "This is a matter of life and death. I don't know what we're waiting for," says @JennieJoseph, founder and executive director of Commonsense Childbirth, about drastically expanding access to pre-childbirth services and education, to tackle the maternal mortality crisis.
author: AndyKroll

text: .@ByNinaMartin: "It's really been very recently that women have been empowered to tell their stories about much of their lives and experiences. Maternal health has been relegated to" private spaces, especially for women of color.
author: AndyKroll

text:
"The bottom line is this: This is something we can actually solve for," @SenKamalaHarris says.

She wraps up her brief remarks by twice saying, "If something's worth fighting for, it's a fight worth having." #blackmomsmatter
author: AndyKroll

text:
"This is one of those truths that must be spoken," says @SenKamalaHarris about the crisis of maternal mortality for black mothers in America. 

The US, Harris says, is 1 of 13 nations where rates of pregnancy-related death and illness are WORSE than they were 25 years ago.
author: AndyKroll

text: .@SenKamalaHarris speaks at @amprog about the crisis of maternal mortality for black mothers, who are 3x to 4x more likely to die than white woman "because they choose to become mothers."

text:
“At some point, I was like: My name is totally destroyed,” says Comet Ping Pong owner James Alefantis. “I just didn’t want anyone to come shoot us up again.”

Inside the aftermath of Pizzagate, the viral conspiracy theory that ushered in the post-truth era
author: AndyKroll

text: Every single word of this. @OfficialJLD is a national treasure
author: AndyKroll

text: This is an absolutely essential work of journalism. Powerfully reveals a horrific yet disturbingly common crime and tragedy. This will no doubt save lives.
author: AndyKroll

text: CODA/ Thanks to @annamerlan, @oneunderscore__, @willsommer, @KELLYWEILL, @Bernstein, @jaredlholt, @travis_view, @ehananoki, @oliverdarcy, @cwarzel + others I'm forgetting whose great work I read tons of and who are so good on this subject.
author: AndyKroll

text:
12/END These conspiracy theories never really go away. Those who peddle them just move on to stuff like QAnon. 

But Podesta's and Alefantis' stories deepen our understanding of them — and maybe offer a playbook for fighting back. @longform @longreads https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-features/john-podesta-pizzagate-766489/ …
author: AndyKroll

text:
11/ Make no mistake: Alefantis still gets harassed. 

This fall, he was accosted on the street in New York City ***after leaving therapy*** with an ex still rattled by the Pizzagate nightmare. For real:
author: AndyKroll

text:
10/ Today, business at Comet Ping Pong is back to pre-Pizzagate levels. 

The threats have mostly died down — though look at the mentions on Podesta's tweet today, citing my story, for a reminder that the Pizzagaters are very much still out there on @Twitter.
author: AndyKroll

text: 9/ John Podesta told me he thought about litigation, too. But he's much more of a public figure than Alefantis and says it would be extremely hard for him to file, say, a defamation suit. Here's more from him on that:
author: AndyKroll

text:
8/ So, what *did* work? 

A legal strategy. 

The firm Boies Schiller Flexner agreed to represent Alefantis, and they pressured Pizzagate's loudest proponents. In March 2017, InfoWars host Alex Jones apologized and retracted multiple Pizzagate-themed broadcasts.
author: AndyKroll

text:
7/ The traditional crisis communications playbook didn't do squat, either. 

Alefantis even went on @MegynKelly's Fox News show to rebut Pizzagate. (Watch: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YXApkzwKIh8 …) But that didn't seem to change anyone's minds and, if anything, it FED the trolls
author: AndyKroll
AndyKroll

text:
5/ Alefantis says the local police were fairly responsive early on. But he got nowhere reporting these threats to the FBI.

Law enforcement didn't seem take his situation too seriously — or grasp the seriousness of Pizzagate — until the gunman showed up.
author: AndyKroll

text:
4/ Those were the starting points for my conversations with Podesta and Alefantis.

The stories they told me were harrowing - death threats, non-stop online harassment, ugly, ugly stuff. Stuff like this
author: AndyKroll

text:
3/ In the two years since, our understanding has grown re: online conspiracies — how they emerge, the people who believe and spread those theories. 

But what about the victims? What's it like to be on the receiving end? How do you fight back against an obvious lie?
author: AndyKroll

text:
2/ Two years ago this month, a 28-year-old man with a revolver & an AR-15 walked into the Comet Ping Pong pizzeria to "investigate" Pizzagate. 

He fired several shots. No one was hurt, but the attack traumatized a community, including Comet owner James Alefantis and his staff.
author: AndyKroll

It's almost impossible to draw connections between the three SoCal cyberattacks apart from their geographic proximity. But remember: If Democrats want to retake the House, they NEED wins in Southern California, which has become the new hot spot for cyberattacks in 2018.
author: AndyKroll

text:
7/ What does this all mean in terms of the midterms? 

Today's story marks the THIRD California Dem to be targeted by cyberattacks. These three Dems all lost their primary campaigns, but there's a good chance the CA Dems who advanced to the general have faced cyberattacks, too.
author: AndyKroll

text: 6/ The social media companies — Twitter, Facebook, YouTube — get most of the scrutiny when it comes to cyberwarfare. But Amazon or other cloud computing companies utilized by malicious actors deserve scrutiny too. (Amazon wouldn't comment on the record for my story. See below.)
author: AndyKroll

text: 5/ Here's a recurring theme from the experts I spoke to that I'm still thinking about: 2016 was a turning point in the U.S. Before, DDoS was more common in conflict zones and developing democracies. But '16 showed how vulnerable our elections are — and made us an ripe target.
author: AndyKroll

text: 4/ One reason DDoS has become so widespread is the amount of computing power out there has increased so dramatically. In Caforio's case, the attacker(s) used Amazon Web Service servers, which is available to anyone for a small amount of $$$.
author: AndyKroll

text: Today it's just a few clicks on your laptop/phone and the effect is the same...
author: AndyKroll

text:
3/ I'm surprised that we haven't heard about more DDoS attacks on U.S. candidates. It's frighteningly easy to launch one.

"All you need to launch an attack today," one cybersecurity expert told me, "is an internet connection and a few dollars."
author: AndyKroll

text:
2/ This is the *first* known apparent DDoS attack on a congressional candidate in '18. In this case, California Dem @BryanCaforio. 

DDoS is essentially the online version of a phone-jamming scam. But the effect is real — silencing a candidate in the middle of his/her campaign.
author: AndyKroll

text:
A Democratic candidate in California who challenged "Putin's favorite congressman" was targeted by a series of cyberattacks—including the same type of spear-phishing hack that exposed the Clinton campaign.

My exclusive story for @RollingStone:
author: AndyKroll

text: Ref to and riff on new travis scott album?
author: AndyKroll

text: 11/ I’ll end on this note: The Keirstead campaign is not the only congressional campaign to face these kinds of attacks. I’ve heard similar reports from other campaigns, and I have no doubt these attacks will continue. Here’s what Keirstead’s former campaign manager told me:
author: AndyKroll

text: 10/ But everyone I spoke to made this clear: The volume and sophistication of the cyberattacks on Keirstead and his campaign strongly suggest the hacker(s) had done research and had a good deal of technical savvy. Esp. when it came to the attempted cloud-server attacks.
author: AndyKroll

text: 9/ IP addresses, phony email accounts, failed login data: They're all useful data points, but they can all easily be manipulated or used to obscure the real source of a cyberattack. That’s why we list potential sources in the story — and don’t go further. (@FBI didn't comment.)
author: AndyKroll

text: 8/ That raises the question of: Who did it? Russia? Another nation-state? Organized crime? A hacktivist with an axe to grind? Unlike the Claire McCaskill hacking attempt reported by the @dailybeast, experts say the Keirstead attacks are much harder to nail down re attribution.
author: AndyKroll

text: 7/ The experts I interviewed say the @FBI took the attacks on Keirstead seriously based on the # of agents involved (across two states) and the data requested. In other words, it’s not just 2016 attacks the FBI is scrutinizing; it’s ongoing attacks, too.
author: AndyKroll

text: 6/ The Democratic Party seems to have learned the lessons of 2016. Documents I obtained show that senior @DCCC officials were quick to respond to Keirstead attacks. It was the @DCCC that successfully alerted the @FBI. (The campaign had previously contacted the @FBI with no luck.)
author: AndyKroll

text: 5/ Then it was Keirstead’s campaign and digital infrastructure that was attacked. There was a stream of suspicious login attempts to the website and brute-force attacks on the hosting service used by the campaign. Again, multiple targets and multiple vectors.
author: AndyKroll

text: 4/ Candidates: If you have a business, you have to fortify your email and IT on that end, too. It’s not enough to lock down your personal or campaign email accounts and other IT. Everything is a target.
author: AndyKroll

text: 3/ First, he was spear-phished, akin to what happened to John Podesta on the Clinton campaign. In Podesta’s case, it was his Gmail. In Keirstead’s case, it was his company email (which he had used on the campaign). Hackers will target any account that they can find.
author: AndyKroll

text: 2/ Dr. Hans Keirstead, a Democrat who ran against Rep. Dana Rohrabacher in CA’s 48th district, faced multiple cyberattacks in the months leading up to the nonpartisan, top-two June 5 primary. Keirstead would lose by less than 150 votes. (His campaign doesn't blame the hacks.)
author: AndyKroll

text: 1/ I want to break out a few important points about this California hacking scoop of mine for @RollingStone — and what it tells us about what to expect in the 2018 midterms.
author: AndyKroll

text: SCOOP: Documents obtained by @RollingStone show a series of hacking attempts—including a successful spear-phishing message—that targeted a Democrat who challenged pro-Russia Rep. Dana Rohrabacher. The FBI has investigated. https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-news/california-election-hacking-711202/ …

text: The Beltway's idea of  blockbuster entertainment
author: AndyKroll

text: Unite the Right 2.0 was so minuscule, so hard to see among the cops and barricades, that it was possible to stand in Lafayette Park among the counter-protesters and imagine that they were chanting at the White House itself.
author: AndyKroll

text:
Unite the Right 2.0 was a big ol' nothingburger. But don't be fooled into thinking the alt-right is on the run.

My on-the-ground dispatch from yesterday's scene at Lafayette Park. https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-news/nazis-in-the-rain-710404/ …
author: AndyKroll

text: Police are clearing the streets around the White House. They're moving the plow trucks that were blocking the intersections. Everyone seems to be heading home. That's a wrap, folks.
author: AndyKroll

text: There's a brief shouting match at the intersection of 17th and I Sts. An antifa-looking guy starts screaming at another protester he thought was with the white nationalists. The other guy spins around, shows him his jacket says ANTIFA too. That's been the day, in a nutshell.
author: AndyKroll

text: The counter protesters aren't quite sure what to do now, with the actual Unite the Right 2.0 over almost as fast as it started. People are marching up 17th Street away from the White House. Unclear where they're going.
author: AndyKroll

text: Police make an announcement: "The group has left the area. Clear the streets and get on the sidewalk!"
author: AndyKroll

text: Big clump of black-clad counterprotesters -- antifa? Black bloc? -- parked outside the western entrance to the WH/Lafayette Park. Things seem to have cooled off for now.
author: AndyKroll

text: Counterprotesters shooting off fireworks in front of the police at the western entrance to the White House/Lafayette Park. Crowd and cops getting edgy.
author: AndyKroll

text: Again, I can't get closer to them because @NatlParkService and @usparkpolicepio cut off media accessibility an hour or more before the event was scheduled to start.
author: AndyKroll

text: Best I can tell, this is the much smaller actual Unite the Right 2.0 event on the south end of Lafayette Park.
author: AndyKroll

text: DC Metropolitan Police says the @NatlParkService has cut off all media access to Unite the Right event -- **1 hour before it begins.** cc @usparkpolicepio
author: AndyKroll

text: Collection of signs among the counterprotesters...
author: AndyKroll

text: Law enforcement has Lafayette Park, site of the Unite the Right event, divided up: small group (as of 4:15p) of white nationalists, neo-Nazis, etc on one side of the park. A much larger contingent of counterprotesters barricaded off on opposite side.
author: AndyKroll

text: Chant breaks out among small group of counterprotesters: "Racists don't have right to free speech!"
author: AndyKroll

text: Another big counter-protest march in the intersection just north of Lafayette Park. "The people united will never be defeated." Still haven't found the actual Unite the Right event...
author: AndyKroll

text: Huge police presence at the west entrance to the White House for Unite the Right 2.0
author: AndyKroll

text: Unite the Right counter-protesters about two blocks from the White House slowly making their way to Lafayette Park
author: AndyKroll

text: Welcoming party for Unite the Right 2.0 attendees exiting at the Foggy Bottom DC Metro station.
author: AndyKroll

text: On my way to cover Unite the Right 2.0 here in D.C. Helicopter circling overhead, been there for an hour. Follow me for updates throughout the day...
author: AndyKroll

Who's Rick Gates? Why is he so important in the Paul Manafort trial?

Your questions answered—and your daily Manafort fix—right here at @RollingStone:
author: AndyKroll

text:
It's Day 6 of the Manafort trial. My midday check-in boils to four words:

"At Mr. Manafort's direction."

That's what ex-Manafort colleague Rick Gates keeps saying. Manafort, he says, orchestrated these alleged crimes. We'll find out v soon if defense attys can break Gates down.
author: AndyKroll

text:
Rick Gates took the stand in a dark suit and gold tie, speaking in a quick, clear, almost boyish tone. He never looked over at his former boss. Paul 

Manafort set his gaze on Gates and kept it there.

Inside the courtroom on Day 5 of the Manafort trial:
author: AndyKroll

text:
Want to know what it was like in the courtroom when Rick Gates testified against his former boss and ex-Trump adviser Paul Manafort?

I. Got. You. My Day 5 dispatch ==>

https://www.rollingstone.com/politics/politics-news/rick-gates-paul-manafort-707509/ …
author: AndyKroll

text:
Day 5 in the Manafort trial:

RICK GATES TIME. 

Gates testified clearly and repeatedly that he and Manafort committed crimes -- often, Gates said, "at Mr. Manafort's direction."

Manafort glowered at Gates the whole time. It was quite a scene. 

Watch this space for my story...

text: And that's the end. @nickconfessore is right: This "independent" audit reads like a sloppy, mediocre press release for Cambridge Analytica. Hardly worth your time...unless you're looking for a laugh. FIN/
author: AndyKroll

text: Aha! The audit finds some tiny fault by Cambridge—obtaining "incorrect visas" for its foreign employees working in US elections. But EVEN HERE, the audit all but absolves CA of any wrongdoing. 17/
author: AndyKroll

text: Typos throughout the audit like this one. (Should be SCL.) Sigh. 16/
author: AndyKroll

text: Again with the pointless footnotes! Remember writing papers for English class and pumping up the font size and adding a bunch of footnotes to meet the length requirement? Yeah, that's what this report feels like. 15/
author: AndyKroll

text: More crack investigating by the Cambridge auditors regarding a supposed bribery scheme in St. Kitts and Nevis. 14/
author: AndyKroll

text: Glad we cleared that up. 13/
author: AndyKroll

text:
Audit: "I have no reason to doubt Nix's sincerity on this."

Nix in undercover video: "These are things that, I mean, it sounds a dreadful thing to say but these are things that don't necessarily need to be true, as long as they're believed." 12/
author: AndyKroll

text: OH CMON 11/
author: AndyKroll

text:
Remember Cambridge's claim that it deleted all the Facebook data it possessed after Facebook demanded it do so?

This is how the audit says it verified Cambridge's claim 10/
author: AndyKroll

text:
There is lots of psychological research drawing connections of various kinds between Facebook likes and personality types: https://applymagicsauce.com/research.html 

You can honestly argue with that research. But this audit's attempt to do so, in a tossed-off footnote (p. 14), is farcical. 9/
author: AndyKroll

text: And frankly (unintentional) parody in some places.
author: AndyKroll

text:
The audit dismisses Chris Wylie @chrisinsilico as a part-time student intern who did little, if anything, of substance for SCL/Cambridge.

That doesn't pass a straight-face test. Wylie's testimony to Parliament, docs he provided, emails he's on—he was FAR more than an intern. 8/
author: AndyKroll

text:
The audit's authors write that "traditional media’s power to influence elections, which was considerable, is on the wane" and that explains the "tone" of the media's reporting on Cambridge.

Well-supported, factually sound conclusion right there. Yeesh. 7/
author: AndyKroll

text:
Wait, it gets better: The Cambridge audit report has a footnote explaining what free will doctrine is.

So far this rigorous "audit" reads more like a B-minus college term paper. 6/
author: AndyKroll

text:
The audit includes a section that defines "data" and says it is "difficult to express" how our data is collected and how much of it is out there.

Hm. Doesn't seem like that complicated of a concept to me... 5/
author: AndyKroll

text:
The audit found that Cambridge did "very little or no due diligence...as to the legitimacy of prospective clients." CA's head data scientist admitted that this was the case.

What happens when you don't vet potential clients? This: https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2018/03/cambridge-analytica-undercover-video-alexander-nix/ … 3/
author: AndyKroll

text:
The report parrots Cambridge's line of defense that it wasn't all that different from other data and political firms.

But in November 2016, then-CEO Alexander Nix raved about how "revolutionary" and "cutting-edge" Cambridge's methods were. https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/cambridge-analytica-congratulates-president-elect-donald-trump-and-vice-president-elect-mike-pence-300359987.html … 2/
author: AndyKroll

text:

text:
12/ Sinclair terminated Leiberman for breach of contract for speaking out. It sued him. AND it fought him over unemployment benefits after he left. 

You can perhaps understand why current anchors are hesitant to speak out.
https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/4053853-Sinclair-Newscentral-v-Leiberman-Complaint-2005.html …
author: AndyKroll

text: 11/ One final thought: If you're wondering why anchors at Sinclair stations aren't speaking up, think about Sinclair's legal battle with Jon Leiberman, the political reporter who criticized Sinclair's planned anti-Kerry movie in 2004.
author: AndyKroll

text:
10/ The producer also said he was asked about his own political leanings in his job interview. 

One Q: whether he thought Jesse Jackson "was a uniter or a divider."
Another: if you had to tell three people to shut up, who would they be?
Another: his opinions of Rush Limbaugh
author: AndyKroll

text:
9/ And according to the producer, Sinclair's Mark Hyman asked to given every copy of this homage/roast tape to benefit MD Gov. Ehrlich because Hyman "was concerned that it not be distributed for wide use."

I wonder why...
author: AndyKroll

text: 8/ In other words, Sinclair allegedly used one of its employees to produce—using company equipment and on company time—an "homage" of sorts for a politician to be used at a political event!
author: AndyKroll

text: 7/ Here's a really juicy detail: The producer says in the deposition that his boss, a Sinclair exec and pundit named Mark Hyman, had the producer make an "homage" video/roast tape for then-Maryland Gov. Bob Ehrlich (a Republican).
author: AndyKroll

text: 6/ The producer described Sinclair's company culture, circa the early to mid 2000s, as "highly suspicious of people...who were not of their belief system."
author: AndyKroll

text: 5/ The producer says he was told to read three books when he arrived at Sinclair: "Slander" by Ann Coulter, "Bias" by Fox talking head Bernard Goldberg, and a third whose title includes the line "How Crusading for Diversity Has Corrupted American Journalism."
author: AndyKroll

text:
4/ This producer said that David Smith, then Sinclair's top exec, had a real affinity for Rush Limbaugh. Smith allegedly urged the producer to listen to Rush. Rush, Smith said, "really gets it." 

Smith didn't urge the producer to read left-leaning sites.
author: AndyKroll

One of defendants tells Fox producers and talent that a forthcoming (false) story connecting Rich to Wikileaks showed that "there was no collusion" https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/4410424-Rich-family-complaint-March-13-2018.html …
author: AndyKroll

text: In their complaint, they're seeking monetary damages decided by a jury trial. You can read the entire complaint here: https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/4410424-Rich-family-complaint-March-13-2018.html … 7/7
author: AndyKroll

text: Mary Rich has said that the "scurrilous allegations" about Seth were like "like burying [her son] all over again." In a joint statement, the Riches say: “No parent should ever have to live through what we have been forced to endure.” 6/
author: AndyKroll

text: That retracted story—and how it came to be published—is at the heart of this lawsuit brought by Joel and Mary Rich. They accused the reporter who wrote that story and a Fox contributor who helped her with having “intentionally exploited" the Riches. 5/
author: AndyKroll

text: In May 2017, a Fox News reporter published a story claiming just that, quoting sources who said there was a Rich-Wikileaks connection. But that story fell apart almost immediately, and it was retracted a week later. 4/
author: AndyKroll

text: But in the absence of definitive answers, Rich's death became a conspiracy theory on the right—namely, that Rich was killed for leaking DNC emails to Wikileaks. 3/
author: AndyKroll

text: You'll remember that 27-year-old Seth Rich, a DNC staffer who was working on expanding voter rights, was shot and killed early on the morning of July 20, 2016. Police have never caught the killers and believe that the crime was a botched robbery. 2/
author: AndyKroll

text: Shutdown threats cause major harm even if a shutdown is avoided. Here's what a soldier said in 2011 about the near-shutdown: http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2018/01/congress-government-shutdown-costs-daca-trump/ …
author: AndyKroll

text:
What are the costs of gov't shutdown brinksmanship?

- Bureau of Prisons said it paid an extra $5.4 mil for a contract to build a prison in West Virginia. 
- Veterans Health Admin. lost $1 mil in lost productivity at VA medical facilities.

More here ==>
author: AndyKroll

text: And horrible for hiring too. A public policy expert at U-Maryland put it well: “The ultimate result is that people leave. And the people who leave are the people who have options, and those are the people you don’t want to leave.”
author: AndyKroll

text: It’s horrible for morale. Here’s what one federal employee told me: “Just the words ‘furlough,’ ‘shutdown,’ you’re thinking, ‘Oh, I have to put my life on hold.’”
author: AndyKroll

text: Take it from a former EPA higher-up: “It’s like if you were a homeowner but literally every month you had to decide if you were going to move on the first of the month or not. Even without the shutdown, there was a cost to taxpayers and to the country.”
author: AndyKroll

text:
All this government shutdown brinksmanship? It’s a massive waste and a huge cost to taxpayers—even when a shutdown *doesn’t* happen. 

My latest: http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2018/01/congress-government-shutdown-costs-daca-trump/ …
